note_en:
Pre-installed malware has been discovered on another budget handset connected to Assurance Wireless by Virgin Mobile.
    Back in January, cybersecurity researchers from Malwarebytes discovered  unremovable malware bundled with the Android operating systems on the Unimax (UMX) U686CL, a low-end handset sold by Assurance Wireless as part of the  Lifeline Assistance program, a 1985 US initiative which subsidizes telephone services for low-income families.
 There was no way to remove a pair of apps on the handsets which would install other software on the devices without the user's knowledge.
  The smartphone in question is the ANS (American Network Solutions) UL40, running Android OS 7.1.1.
   Malwarebytes researcher Nathan Collier  said on Wednesday that following January's report, followers of the company said that a variety of ANS phone models were subject to the same problems -- however, without handling a physical device, these claims were difficult to verify.
 The team was able to get their hands on an ANS UL40 for investigation. While it is not clear if the device is still directly on sale by Assurance Wireless, the user manual is still listed on the vendor's website -- inaccessible at the time of writing -- and the handset can still be purchased via other online stores and marketplaces.
   In the same way as the UMX U686CL, two apps -- a settings app and wireless update app -- are compromised. However, these apps are not infected with the same malware variants; instead, Collier says the "infections are similar but have their own unique infection characteristics."
 The Settings app is detected as Downloader Wotby, a Trojan that is able to download apps externally. The researchers did not find any evidence of malicious apps in a third-party store linked to the software but noted this doesn't mean that malicious apps could not be added or find their way into the store at a later date.
 The WirelessUpdate app is considered a Potentially Unwanted Program (PUP) that is also able to automatically install apps without user permission or knowledge.
  While the app does function as an over-the-air updater for security fixes and as an updater to the operating system itself, the software also installs four variants of HiddenAds, a Trojan family found on Android handsets.
 HiddenAds is a strain of adware that bombards users with adverts. In order to verify where the malware originated from, Malwarebytes disabled WirelessUpdate and then re-enabled the app. Within 24 hours, four adware strains were covertly installed.
 As the malware on the UMX and ANS differ, the team wanted to see if there were any ties linking the brands. A common thread was the use of a digital certificate used to sign the ANS Settings app under the name teleepoch. Upon further investigation, the certificate was traced back to TeleEpoch Ltd, which is registered as UMX in the United States.
 "We have a Settings app found on an ANS UL40 with a digital certificate signed by a company that is a registered brand of UMX," Collier says. "That's two different Settings apps with two different malware variants on two different phone manufactures & models that appear to all tie back to TeleEpoch Ltd. Additionally, thus far the only two brands found to have preinstalled malware in the Settings app via the Lifeline Assistance program are ANS and UMX."
  According to Collier, the ANS L51 was then examined and was found to have the same malicious apps as the UMX U683CL.
 However, it is unclear as to whether the vendors are at fault, or whether the malicious apps were implemented down the supply chain.
 Once informed of the U683CL's malware issue in January, UMX removed the malicious apps. Malwarebytes says the company has "the utmost faith that ANS will quickly find a resolution to this issue" in the same way.
 "There are tradeoffs when choosing a budget mobile device," Collier commented. "Some expected tradeoffs are performance, battery life, storage size, screen quality, and list of other things in order to make a mobile device light on the wallet. However, budget should never mean compromising one's safety with pre-installed malware. Period."
   Earlier this week, Kasperksy  researchers warned that mobile adware is becoming increasingly sophisticated and difficult to remove from smartphones and tablets. In 14.8% of attacks recorded by the company, malware or adware would infect the system partition, of which removal can lead to device failure.

这个月，一位宇宙来客正在为天空增光添彩。7月3日，一颗彗星掠过太阳，从那以后，肉眼就可以看到它了。从太阳系外瞥见古老冰块的难得机会应该会在下周继续，天文学家希望届时它会变得更加明亮。
3月27日，科学家们使用近地物体广域红外勘测探测器(NEOWISE)太空望远镜首次发现了这颗冲向太阳的彗星。这颗彗星以望远镜的名字非正式地命名为NeOWISE，但官方标记为C/2020 F3，随着阳光和太阳风导致它释放气体并形成尾巴，这颗彗星逐渐变亮。6月初，从地球上看，它到达了太阳的另一边。由此产生的强光使天文学家在几周内无法观测到这颗彗星。然而，到了6月下旬，它又游回了另一架太空望远镜--太阳和日球层天文台(SOHO)的光学系统中。然而，它的命运仍然不明朗：新彗星是会变亮还是会褪色？
7月3日，观察家们密切关注着这颗彗星开始了它旅程中最危险的部分：它最接近太阳的地方，这使它距离我们的恒星不到4400万公里。如此近距离产生的强烈光和热往往会使彗星解体并从夜空中消失。今年早些时候，另外两颗彗星ATLAS和Swan也发生了这样的解体，天文学家曾希望这两颗彗星能照亮地球的天空。但NeOWISE幸存了下来，出现了比以前更明亮的景象，让天文学家们眼花缭乱--前提是他们知道去哪里看。现在，至少在接下来的几天里，北半球的居民可以在黎明时分迎接过往的游客。
“对于北半球的许多人来说，特别是如果你离中纬度更近的话，(彗星)应该在日出前一个小时就能看到，在东北部的天空非常低，”克里-安·莱基·赫本(Kerry-Ann Lecky Hepburn)说。他是一位气象学家和天体摄影师，捕捉到了多伦多上空NEOWISE彗星的图像。“现在它位于御夫座。”她建议使用带有互动星座地图的专门智能手机应用程序找到彗星的确切位置。虽然肉眼已经可以看到这个物体，但它仍然很模糊，双筒望远镜可以提供更好的视野。
莱基·赫本说，从7月12日左右开始，NEOWISE彗星也将在晚上出现。日落后大约一个小时，它将出现在西北地平线附近。随着月份的推移，它将在天空中升得更高，从山猫星座向北斗七星移动。7月22日，这颗彗星将到达距离地球最近的一点-1.03亿公里-然后继续其宇宙飞行。然而，到那时它是否仍然可以用肉眼看到还不确定。
“彗星就像猫，”SETI研究所的天文学家弗兰克·马奇斯(Franck Marchis)说。“他们是不可预测的。”如果NEOWISE彗星的放气耗尽了它储存的冰物质，它明亮的尾巴可能会消散，有效地将该物体从视野中移走。在另一个极端，来自太阳的持续加热可能导致彗星在明亮的爆发中解体，潜在地导致一颗具有历史意义的高度可见的“伟大的彗星”。马奇斯说，这种可能性将是“一个壮观的事件，对地球人来说是一场伟大的表演”。但“就我个人而言，我建议你早点走过去，趁我们知道它就在这里的时候，现在就去看看。”
在这次相遇之后，天文学家们预计NEOWISE彗星将在相当长的一段时间内告别。它围绕我们的恒星的漫长而循环的轨道将在大约6800年后将它带回地球附近。

This month a cosmic visitor is gracing the skies. A comet swept past the sun on July 3, and it has since become visible to the naked eye. The rare opportunity to glimpse the chunk of ancient ice from the outer solar system should continue next week, when astronomers hope it will become even brighter.
  Scientists using the Near-Earth Object Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (NEOWISE) space telescope first spotted the comet as it hurtled toward the sun on March 27. Informally dubbed NEOWISE after the telescope but officially labeled C/2020 F3, the comet gradually brightened as sunlight and solar wind caused it to release gases and form a tail. In early June it reached the far side of the sun, as seen from Earth. The resulting glare prevented astronomers from observing the comet for several weeks. By late June, however, it swam back into the optics of another space telescope, the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO). Its fate was still unclear, however: Would Comet NEOWISE brighten or fade?
  On July 3 observers watched closely as the comet began the most perilous part of its journey: its nearest approach to the sun, which brought it within 44 million kilometers of our star. The intense light and heat from such close proximity tends to make comets disintegrate and disappear from the night sky. Earlier this year, such breakups befell two other comets, ATLAS and SWAN, that astronomers had hoped would light up Earth’s skies. But NEOWISE survived and emerged brighter than before to dazzle stargazers—provided they know where to look. Now, for the next few days at least, residents of the Northern Hemisphere can greet the passing visitor at dawn.
  “For many people in the Northern Hemisphere, especially if you’re closer to the midlatitudes, [the comet] should be visible an hour before sunrise, very low in the northeastern sky,” says Kerry-Ann Lecky Hepburn, a meteorologist and astrophotographer who  captured an image of Comet NEOWISE over Toronto. “Right now it’s located in the constellation Auriga.” She recommends finding the comet’s exact spot using specialized smartphone apps with interactive maps of the constellations. Although already visible to the naked eye, the object is still faint, and binoculars would offer a better view.
  Starting around July 12, Comet NEOWISE will be visible in the evening as well, Lecky Hepburn says. About an hour after sunset, it will appear near the northwestern horizon. As the month progresses, it will rise higher in the sky, moving from the constellation Lynx toward the Big Dipper. On July 22 the comet will reach its closest point to Earth—a distance of 103 million kilometers—before continuing its cosmic flight. Whether it will still be visible to unaided eyes by then is uncertain, however.
  “Comets are like cats,” says Franck Marchis, an astronomer at the SETI Institute. “They are unpredictable.” If Comet NEOWISE’s outgassing exhausts its reserves of icy material, its bright tail could dissipate, effectively removing the object from view. On the other extreme, ongoing heating from the sun could cause the comet to disintegrate in a bright outburst, potentially resulting in a highly visible “great comet” of historic significance. This possibility would be “a spectacular event and a great show for the earthlings,” Marchis says. But “personally, I recommend walking up early and going to see it now, while we know it’s here.”
  After this encounter, astronomers expect Comet NEOWISE to bid farewell for quite some time. Its long, looping orbit around our star will next bring it back to Earth’s vicinity some 6,800 years from now.
    Have you managed to spot and photograph Comet NEOWISE? Send Scientific American  your favorite images on Twitter  @sciam with the hashtag #EyesOnNEOWISE.

As you might have heard, Living Computers: Museum+Labs has shut down; its doors will remain closed for at least the next twelve to eighteen months, and the staff is off to find new adventures.
  I have had the honor of being an engineer at LCM+L for the last five years and I am still struggling to come to terms with this -- I've had time to let the shock settle in since I heard the news a month ago and I am still unable to really grasp the finality of the situation.  I don't know how to say goodbye.
  These past few weeks I have been working on-site at the museum, helping to shut things down in an orderly fashion.  It feels like I'm preparing to bury a close friend, building an ornate wooden box, polishing it, lining it and driving the nails in.  Digging a hole.  Preparing some final words.
  And it really is a living, breathing entity that we're saying goodbye to; this museum is an undertaking that spans decades and has involved the blood, sweat, and tears of every person that has worked here.  It encompasses the souls and dreams and ideas of dozens of dedicated individuals -- educators, engineers, guest services, archivists, curators and benefactors. This museum that we built together has touched many thousands of lives across the world and each of them in turn has added something of their own.  It is meaningful, and it is important.
    I helped shut the big systems down on Monday with the rest of the engineering staff.  I have never heard the computer room this quiet before.  I'd be lying if I didn't shed a tear when turning Rosencrantz (the VAX, running perpetually for a decade) off, wondering when it would run again.
  Every artifact I look at as I wander through the rows of computers in the museum's basement brings back memories, or a longing for potential now out of reach.  I remember some of the first things I did after joining the team -- restoring the Interdata 7/32 and getting Wollongong V6 UNIX running for the first time and being able to share that with the world was really something else.  Working on the Alto emulator, I found myself chatting with legends from Xerox PARC, an experience that will be tough to top.  In the months before we closed, we all worked together to get V0 UNIX running on our restored PDP-7 and in so doing brought some truly important history back to life.
  I almost got over my fear of public speaking doing our engineering gallery talks and I came to realize that I actually enjoyed it.  I loved chatting with visitors, and the enthusiasm they all had for the place was amazing.
  We all did some amazing things here.  We all have so many stories and memories.  We all have so much to be proud of.
  I want to thank all the wonderful folks I worked with at LCM.  This has been the greatest job I've ever had and that's due in no small part to the people I shared it with.  I will miss you all.  I also want to thank everyone who came to visit the museum over these many years -- thank you for letting us share it with you.  I have met so many new people, shared so many stories and have learned so many extremely cool things and I will never, ever forget it.
  Today was my last day.  At 5:45pm I walked out of the doors of the museum for the last time.  The hurt is still here in my heart as I write this but I know things will get better and that I will be able to move on.

自从F/A-18A大黄蜂在20世纪80年代问世以来，这座著名的校舍还没有适应过如此高的空战能力。
举世闻名的美国海军战斗机武器学校(NFWS)，也就是更广为人知的TOPGUN，已经开始了其受人尊敬的历史上最大的演变之一。这所学校已经毕业了它的第一批两名F-35C闪电II飞行员，他们是第一批在海军隐形战斗机驾驶舱内接受这种高级水平训练的舰队飞行员。
为期13周的攻击战斗机战术教官(SFTI)课程由位于内华达州法伦海军航空站的海军航空作战发展中心(NAWDC)开办。TopGun是一个个人级别的教学大纲，将大量的实况飞行与课堂学术相结合，旨在向精心挑选的机队飞行员传授最新的高级战术技能，以及如何将这些知识传授给他们的同事飞行员。
美国海军陆战队少校德里克·海因茨(Derek Heinz)和美国海军中尉威廉·古德温三世(William Goodwin III)在5月份完成了这门课程，现在已经回到他们在加利福尼亚州勒莫尔海军航空站的部队。亨氏被分配到打击战斗机中队125(VFA-125)，“野蛮袭击者”，这是一个训练单位，而古德温来自VFA-147，海军第一个F-35C舰队单位。
毕业生们获得了梦寐以求的红蓝相间的TOPGUN补丁，精通校舍提供的最新战术和技术，成为了“佩戴补丁的人”。然后，他们回到舰队，将所学到的知识传播到他们准备好的房间里。
前两名F-35C飞行员毕业于02-20班。闪电II学生的到来标志着TOPGUN自2001年年中05-01级成为第一个通过F/A-18E/F超级大黄蜂的第一个主要平台演变以来的第一次重大平台演变。即使在那时，超级大黄蜂的教学大纲也是现有F/A-18A/C/D大黄蜂计划的变体，早期的“犀牛”共享许多相同的系统和战术。
双角色大黄蜂的到来引发了在TOPGUN增加空对地教学的举措。1993年，它将课程从5周的课程大纲扩大到6周的课程，并增加了空对地阶段。两年后，TOPGUN在推出SFTI课程时，放弃了每个中队培训一名机组人员的模式，到目前为止，SFTI课程涉及机组人员前往法伦，然后在一系列可能的机队任务之间重新分配部分机组人员。从那时起，它就演变成了目前的13周课程结构。
因此，F-35的到来是TOPGUN自20世纪80年代中期该型号投入使用后首次在TOPGUN部署“遗产”大黄蜂课程以来最大的变化之一。最后一批F-14 Tomcat学员在2003年通过了TOPGUN，闪电II的时代代表着海军的重大变革，因为它首次将一架低可见度(隐身)飞机融入其备受尊敬的TOPGUN课程。
NFWS正式是NAWDC内的一个部门，由一名系主任领导，尽管该校的教职员工和学生恭敬地将他们的名义负责人称为指挥官或“船长”。
海军司令蒂莫西·迈尔斯(Timothy‘Ain’t‘Myers)目前是这一享有盛誉的职位的持有者。
我们对通过TOPGUN的学生的关注并不局限于教授他们成功使用飞机所需的战术、技术和程序，这些都是整合到一支更大的部队中的。我们也在教我们的毕业生如何指导其他学生，这样当他们回到舰队时，他们就能够在非常高的水平上指导他们。“。
在过去的几年里，NAWDC和TOPGUN的工作人员一直在为海军最新的战斗机开发新的课程，由经验丰富的教官来培训为F-35C量身定做的技能。美国海军一直对其新的闪电II教学大纲的细节守口如瓶。
“虽然所有的F-35C战术教官之前都已经完成了TOPGUN课程，但这是TOPGUN第一次利用从头开始为F-35C综合作战制定的教学大纲，让目前驾驶闪电II的学生毕业。这是通过将F-35C战术逐步引入到以前课程的训练课程中来实现的。其结果是，一支训练有素的教官干部执行完全整合的F-35C教学大纲，为第五代战斗机提供全面的“研究生级别”培训，以便带回舰队。
虽然美国空军位于内华达州内利斯空军基地的相当松散的武器学校(WPS)是建立在近40年操作低可见(LO)隐形飞机经验的基础上的，但对海军来说，这仍然是相对较新的。2019年2月，海军宣布F-35C已经做好在世界各地部署和执行任务的作战准备，F-35C舰队替换中队(FRS)VFA-125第一批新翼F-35C飞行员毕业。
海军和海军陆战队一直热衷于将其人员嵌入交换项目，以了解操作第五代战斗机的细微差别，但值得注意的是，这两个组织运行着两种不同的战术手册。海军陆战队使用美国空军的一个版本的“3-1”(三破折号-1)，至少在F-35B方面是这样，而海军已经为F-35C开发了自己的作战概念(CONOPS)，目前正在TOPGUN进行改进。
法伦的第一个F-35C课程仅仅是故事的开始，TOPGUN的工作人员已经在寻找经验教训，以及如何进一步完善这种先进战斗机的教学大纲，以最好地满足海军的未来需求。
美国空军F-22以能够潜入战斗并在不被发现的情况下提供致命一击而闻名。F-35将把同样的能力带入TOPGUN竞技场，到目前为止，TOPGUN竞技场一直由非隐形和不那么复杂的平台主导。
虽然TOPGUN仍然侧重于空对空训练，但现有的大黄蜂和超级大黄蜂教学大纲包括空对地阶段。有趣的是，为期13周的课程没有延长到第一个F-35C级，但操作一架低可见性(隐身)和极其先进的战斗机的额外复杂性可能需要随着时间的推移进一步扩大教学大纲。课程的长度表明，F-35C的教学大纲在核心要素方面很可能遵循超级大黄蜂的教学大纲，经过调整以采用隐形战术和新技术。
对于超级大黄蜂，课程分为四个主要阶段：基本战斗机机动(BFM又名斗狗)；空对地；分段空对空(两舰)；师(四舰)。除了只有两周的空对地模块外，每个模块的运行时间都在三周到三周半之间。
TopGun没有分配F-35Cs。学生们从自己的部队驾驶飞机，02-20班的许多闪电II架次直接从加利福尼亚州的NAS Lemoore(VFA-125和VFA-147的母站)飞越法伦靶场训练综合体。这也为学生们提供了在他们的常驻模拟器中排练任务的机会。
值得注意的是，到目前为止，TOPGUN课程的重点是实况飞行，然而，先进的模拟器和更高级别的闪电II安全分类的出现意味着一部分活动可能已经在综合环境中完成，而且这只会随着时间的推移而增长。众所周知，海军已经研究了空军研究实验室的安全实时、虚拟和建设性的高级训练环境(SLATE)计划，该计划可以提供那种实时、虚拟、建设性(LVC)的训练，这将成为TOPGUN的核心部分，对战斗机集成至关重要。
将模拟器中的综合训练与飞行实况飞行的飞行员相结合，可以实现许多重要功能。对于F-35C来说，最重要的元素之一是能够在安全的环境中训练武器系统，而不是潜伏在训练范围内的窥探，并能够解读在实弹飞行中展示的敏感信息，如雷达和电子战的签名和能力。飞机的电子战能力也可能受到训练环境和训练地点的限制。
LVC还允许混合新功能和探索场景，而不必将所有物理元素集合在一起。例如，在Lemoore的模拟器中，一名F-35C飞行员理论上可以与一名飞行员一起训练，该飞行员在F/A-18型飞机上在法伦山脉上空执行实况任务，至少在可视范围内。或者，可以添加威胁，实际上是为了让飞行员练习对它们的最新规定反应。
然而，实况飞行的BFM仍然是TOPGUN教学大纲的一个关键要素，重点是在驾驶舱内战斗的身体挑战。合成的训练辅助设备将对飞行员学习如何从超视距(BVR)过渡到近距离竞技场很有用。教官们高度重视如何利用对手的错误，并将其转化为进攻优势，这是出了名的难以在模拟器中复制，几乎达到了与对手实际飞行的逼真度。
BFM阶段的目的是提高学生在高重力下操纵飞机时的技能，同时保持对对手的视线，并在电话亭里进行众所周知的持刀格斗。学生们与TOPGUN教官正面交锋，最初是类似类型的，然后招募推重比明显更高的灵活的NAWDC F-16A/B“毒蛇”来增加赌注。学生和教官在每次任务后冗长的汇报会议上极其详细地研究这些BFM任务，其重要性怎么强调都不为过。
当涉及到F-35C的加入时，远程BVR项目很可能是TOPGUN变化最大的地方。通过雷达探测射程内的对手和使用AIM-120先进中程空对空导弹(AMRAAM)玩猫鼠游戏的传统场景已经不复存在。理论上，如果隐形F-35处于完全低可见的状态，在不被发现的情况下击毙敌人，或者至少不会被发现，以至于敌人可以先发动致命一击，那么它可以在一定程度上不受惩罚。
从远程到近距离战斗的传统过渡是另一个可能给TOPGUN工作人员带来特别挑战的领域。F-35B和C没有像F-35A那样的内置炮，如果任务需要，必须携带吊舱GAU-22/A加农炮，这也否定了飞机在安装时的隐身能力。所有F-35战机都在外部携带其近距离空对空热寻的AIM-9X响尾蛇导弹，这也降低了喷气式飞机在安装时的隐身雷达信号。这对任何类型的F-35从远程隐形无声攻击过渡到近距离战斗的能力构成了重大挑战。基本上，与没有安装响尾蛇时相比，当飞机的签名与外部安装的响尾蛇受损时，飞机在空战中的使用方式会有很大的不同。仅仅局限于内部携带的AIM-120 AMRAAM导弹本身就有很大的不同。
TOPGUN很有可能已经引入了战术，重点是在可视范围内使用AMRAAM，以允许一架隐形配置的F-35C在两个区域之间移动。这是一种已知的战术，已经在战斗中使用过，特别是2017年6月TOPGUN海军研究生海军少校迈克尔·“暴徒”特雷梅尔在叙利亚上空使用的战术。TOPGUN章程的一部分就是解决这类问题，找到解决办法，促进最佳实践。这些关于F-35C的独特问题正是TOPGUN专家为了发展教学大纲而仔细审查并反馈到系统中的。
NAWDC在2019年末仅使用TOPGUN教师进行了教学大纲的演练，今年早些时候开始了与学生的第一次现场课程。此外，空中测试和评估第九中队(VX-9)，即“吸血鬼”，在将F-35C纳入TOPGUN课程的过程中发挥了重要作用，特别是考虑到其广泛的作战范围。
F-35C为航母空中联队增加了对竞争激烈的环境的深度打击能力，但此外，该飞机将在执行攻击性反空(OCA)和防御性反空(DCA)任务集的同时，执行摧毁敌人防空(DEAD)的任务。
F-35C可能给现有的TOPGUN课程带来的其他变化包括在BVR竞技场使用隐形战术，飞行员充当战斗经理，监控80x20英寸触摸屏驾驶舱显示器，显示通过一系列令人眼花缭乱的先进传感器吸收的数据。F-35飞行员有一个明显的优势，因为飞机的传感器融合程度极高。这架喷气式飞机的AN/APG-81有源电子扫描阵列(AESA)雷达、电光目标系统(EOTS)、分布式孔径系统(DAS)及其高度先进的电子监视和电子战套件协同工作，为飞行员提供前所未有的态势感知。总而言之，与海军目前服役的超级大黄蜂相比，F-35C代表着技术上的重大飞跃。
作为一个为期13周的课程，TOPGUN不能提供像内利斯为期6个月的美国空军武器教官课程(WIC)那样的详细程度。F-35C的复杂性意味着在法伦教授的教学大纲可能需要扩展或以其他方式增加固定的元素。TopGun对空对空作战的关注可能不会理想地适合于深度打击任务可能需要的那种高级任务组合领导。然而，TOPGUN与F-35C的合作将对建立美国海军所需的企业知识产生影响，这些知识将导致成功使用该喷气式飞机的全部能力。
“毕业的攻击战斗机战术教官使我们能够通过将TOPGUN训练反馈给机队来加速学习，提高单个飞机以及航母打击群的杀伤力和生存能力。闪电II在TOPGUN课程的每个阶段都证明了它对海军的价值，它与F/A-18E/F超级大黄蜂、EA-18G Growler和E-2C/D鹰眼的集成表明，第四代和第五代战斗机的强大组合，加上先进的电子攻击和指挥控制，是对抗先进威胁的力量倍增器。“。
自从5月份完成TOPGUN课程以来，Heinz和Goodwin已经回来指导和培训他们的中队成员，特别强调确保飞行员在F-35C的第一次作战部署中拥有有效使用F-35C所需的技能。
“我们的重点是协助作战舰队中队的SFTI推进大局战术，并确保为第一次和随后的F-35C航母部署做好一切准备。我们的想法是，VFA-147SFTI可以使用我们提供的战术执行标准来培训他们自己的人员，并通过部署将这些知识带在他们身上。我们在这里是为了确保它们是为成功而设立的。
虽然我作为一名F-35C教官的角色仍然主要集中在FRS的学生身上，但自从完成TOPGUN以来，我对我教授什么以及如何教授的看法肯定有所增长，“Maj Heinz补充道。“我仍在培训学生驾驶飞机，只是现在，作为SFTI的一名成员，我有额外的责任将先进的培训带给机队，同时帮助维持TOPGUN培训大纲，并确保所有教官培训的标准化。我们一直致力于保持最高水平的培训。“。
自2018年8月联合攻击战斗机联队司令在勒莫尔站立以来，该计划已经为VFA-147和美国军委的第一个F-35C单位-海军陆战队攻击中队314(VMFA-314)-黑骑士宣布了安全飞行作战认证(SFFOC)。VFA-147现在正在为有史以来第一次F-35C航母部署做准备，作为航母空军联队二号(CVW-2)的一部分。联合打击战斗机联队司令、海军上尉阿丹·科瓦鲁比亚斯(Adan Covarrubias)在一份新闻稿中表示：
在第一个F-35C级中开发的战术现在正被整合到航母空军联队的训练周期中，真正使它们成为未来更具杀伤力的航母和空军联队。
在TOPGUN完成第一个F-35C课程的时间非常及时。VFA-147最近集体抵达NAS Fallon，开始中队为即将到来的航母部署做准备，并配备了新的TOPGUN毕业的攻击战斗机战术教官，他已经为中队设定了速度。考虑到这支部队可能会在全球许多热点地区发现自己在第一次巡航时被召入战斗，有一名刚刚从TOPGUN毕业的人加入到它的队伍中，给了Argonauts一个巨大的优势。
这将极大地帮助确保中队可能执行的任何任务都是成功的，并确保每一名F-35C飞行员都能活着回家。
作者注：战区与TOPGUN进行了接触，讨论了新F-35航线的细节，但作战安全阻止了任何进一步的评论。

Not since the introduction of the F/A-18A Hornet in the 1980s has the famed schoolhouse had to adapt to such an advance in air combat capability.
 The world-famous  U.S. Navy Fighter Weapons School (NFWS), better known as TOPGUN, has started down the path of one of the biggest evolutions in its esteemed history. The school has graduated its first two F-35C Lightning II pilots, the first fleet aviators to train at this advanced level in the cockpit of a naval stealth fighter.
 The 13-week Strike Fighter Tactics Instructor (SFTI) course is run by the Naval Aviation Warfighting Development Center (NAWDC) at Naval Air Station Fallon, Nevada. TOPGUN is an individual-level syllabus that combines significant amounts of live flying with classroom academics and is designed to teach handpicked fleet aviators the latest advanced tactical skills and how to impart that knowledge onto their fellow pilots.
 U.S. Marine Corps Major Derek Heinz and U.S. Navy Lieutenant William Goodwin III completed the course in May and have now returned to their units at Naval Air Station Lemoore, in California. Heinz is assigned to Strike Fighter Squadron 125 (VFA-125), the “Rough Raiders,” a training unit, while Goodwin is from VFA-147, the "Argonauts," the Navy’s first F-35C fleet unit.
 The graduates become ‘patch wearers’ having earned the coveted red and blue TOPGUN patch, versed in the latest tactics and techniques that the schoolhouse has to offer. Then they return to the fleet and spread what they have learned around their ready rooms.
  The first two F-35C pilots graduated from Class 02-20. The arrival of Lightning II students marks the first major platform evolution for TOPGUN since Class 05-01 became the first to go through with the F/A-18E/F Super Hornet in mid-2001. Even then, the Super Hornet syllabus was a variation of the existing F/A-18A/C/D Hornet program, with early “Rhinos” sharing many of the same systems and tactics.
 The arrival of the dual-role Hornet triggered a move towards the addition of air-to-ground instruction at TOPGUN. In 1993, it expanded the course from a five-week syllabus to a six-week one with the addition of an air-to-ground phase. Two years later, TOPGUN moved away from the model of training a crew from each squadron as it debuted the SFTI course, which to this day involves aircrews to Fallon and then redistributing some of them between a range of possible fleet assignments. It has since evolved into the current 13-week course structure.
  So, the arrival of the F-35 is one of the biggest changes for TOPGUN since the ‘Legacy’ Hornet course was first fielded at TOPGUN in the mid-1980s after the type’s introduction into service. The last F-14 Tomcat students passed through TOPGUN in 2003, and the era of the Lightning II represents a major step-change for the Navy as it blends a low-observable (stealthy) aircraft into its esteemed TOPGUN course for the first time.
 The NFWS is officially a department within NAWDC, led by a department head, although the school’s staff and students respectfully refer to their figurehead as the Commanding Officer or “Skipper.”
 Navy Commander Timothy ‘Ain’t’ Myers is the current holder of this prestigious position.
 “Our focus on the students that go through TOPGUN is not limited to teaching them the tactics, techniques and procedures that are required for them to successfully employ their aircraft, integrated into a larger force. We are also in the business of teaching our graduates how to instruct other students, so that when they go back to the fleet, they are able to instruct at a very high level,”
 For the last few years, NAWDC and TOPGUN staff have been developing the new curriculum for the Navy’s latest fighter, with suitably experienced instructors to train skill sets tailored to the F-35C. The U.S. Navy has stayed tight-lipped about the specifics of its new Lightning II syllabus.
 “While all F-35C tactics instructors have completed the TOPGUN course previously, this is the first time TOPGUN has graduated students who are currently flying the Lightning II, utilizing a syllabus that has been developed, from the ground up, specifically for F-35C integrated operations. This was accomplished by the gradual introduction of F-35C tactics into the training curriculum for previous classes. The result is a cadre of highly trained instructors executing a fully-integrated F-35C syllabus, providing well-rounded “graduate-level” training for the fifth-generation fighter to take back to the fleet."
 While the U.S. Air Force’s very loosely equivalent  Weapons School, or WPS, at  Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada, has been built upon nearly 40 years of experience in operating low-observable (LO) stealth aircraft, it’s still relatively new for the Navy. In February 2019, the Navy declared that the F-35C was  operationally ready to deploy and conduct missions around the world, and VFA-125, the F-35C Fleet Replacement Squadron (FRS), graduated its first newly winged F-35C aviators
  The Navy and Marine Corps have been keen to embed its personnel in exchange programs in order to understand the nuances of operating a 5th generation fighter, but it’s notable that the two organizations operate two different tactics manuals. The Marines use a version of the U.S. Air Force’s “3-1” (three-dash-one), at least with regards to their F-35Bs, whereas the Navy has developed its own concept of operation (CONOPS) for the F-35C, which is now being refined at TOPGUN.
 The first F-35C class at Fallon is just the start of the story and the TOPGUN staff will already be looking at lessons learned and how to further refine the syllabus for this advanced fighter to best meet the future needs of the Navy.
 The U.S. Air Force  F-22 is renowned for being able to sneak into a fight and deliver a killer blow without being detected. The F-35 will bring some of that same prowess into the TOPGUN arena, which has, until now, been dominated by non-stealthy and less complex platforms.
 While TOPGUN remains weighted towards air-to-air training, the existing Hornet and Super Hornet syllabus includes an air-to-ground phase. Interestingly, the 13-week course was not extended for the first F-35C class, but the additional complexity of operating a low observable (stealthy) and extremely advanced fighter may require further expansion of the syllabus over time. The length of the course suggests that the F-35C syllabus likely follows that of the Super Hornet in terms of core elements, adjusted to embrace stealth tactics and new techniques.
 For the Super Hornet, the course is divided into four main phases: basic fighter maneuvering (BFM aka dogfighting); air-to-surface; section air-to-air (two-ship); and division (four-ship). Each runs for between three and three-and-a-half weeks, except for the air-to-surface module, which is only two weeks.
  TOPGUN has no F-35Cs assigned. The students fly aircraft from their own unit and many of the Lightning II sorties in Class 02-20 were flown over the Fallon Range Training Complex direct from NAS Lemoore, California, the home station of VFA-125 and VFA-147. This also provided the opportunity for the students to rehearse missions in their resident simulators.
 Notably, until now, the TOPGUN course has focused on live flying, however, the advent of  advanced simulators and higher levels of security classification for the Lightning II means that a portion of events will likely have been completed in a synthetic environment, and this will only grow over time. The Navy is known to have looked at the Air Force Research Laboratory’s Secure Live, Virtual and Constructive Advanced Training Environment (SLATE) program, which could offer the kind of Live, Virtual, Constructive (LVC) training that will become a core part of TOPGUN and vital to fighter integration.
 Blending synthetic training in simulators with aviators flying live missions enables a number of important functions. One of the most important elements for the F-35C is the ability to train with the weapons system being “full-up” in a secure environment, away from prying eyes that may be lurking on the training ranges and able to interpret sensitive information that is exhibited in live flying, such as radar and electronic warfare signatures and capabilities. The aircraft's  electronic warfare abilities may also be limited due to the training environment and where that training is happening, as well.
  LVC also allows new capabilities to be blended in and scenarios to be explored without having to bring all the physical elements together. For example, an F-35C pilot in a simulator at Lemoore could theoretically train with a pilot flying a live mission over the Fallon ranges in an F/A-18, at least up until within visual range. Or, threats could be added virtually in order for the pilot to practice the latest prescribed reactions to them.
 However, live-flown BFM remains a key element of the TOPGUN syllabus, with an emphasis on the physical challenges of fighting in the cockpit. Synthetic training aids will be useful for pilots learning how to transition from beyond visual range (BVR) into the close-in arena. The instructors place high emphasis on how to take advantage of the adversary’s mistakes and turn that into an offensive advantage, something that’s notoriously tough to replicate in the simulator with anywhere near the fidelity of actually flying against an opponent.
 The BFM phase is designed to refine the student’s skills when maneuvering the aircraft at high G-forces, while maintaining sight on the opponent and beating them up in the proverbial 'knife fight in a telephone booth.' Students go head-to-head with TOPGUN instructors, initially in similar types, before the nimble  NAWDC F-16A/B “Vipers,” with significantly higher thrust-to-weight ratio, are drafted in to up the ante. The students and instructor pore over these BFM missions in extreme detail during lengthy debriefing sessions after each mission, the importance of which cannot be overemphasized.
  The long-range BVR engagements are likely to be where the biggest changes have come to TOPGUN when it comes to the inclusion of the F-35C. Gone are the traditional scenarios of detecting an opponent at range via radar and playing a cat-and-mouse game with AIM-120 Advanced Medium-Range Air-to-Air Missiles (AMRAAMs). The stealthy F-35 can theoretically operate with some impunity if it is in full low-observable configuration, picking off its foes without ever being seen, or at least without being detected in such a way that an enemy can land a deadly blow first.
 The traditional transition from long-range into close fighting is another area likely to have presented particular challenges for the TOPGUN staff. The F-35B and C don’t feature an internal gun like the F-35A and must carry the  podded GAU-22/A cannon if required for the mission, which also negates the aircraft’s stealth capabilities when fitted. All F-35s also carry their close-range, air-to-air heat-seeking  AIM-9X Sidewinder missiles externally, which also degrades the jet's stealthy radar signature when fitted. This poses a major challenge for any type of F-35 in its ability to transition from long-range stealthy silent attacks, into close-range fights. Basically, the aircraft would be employed very differently in air-to-air combat when its signature is compromised with Sidewinders fitted externally compared to when they are not. Just being limited to the internally carried AIM-120 AMRAAM missile alone is a big difference.
 It’s very possible that TOPGUN has introduced tactics that focus on using the AMRAAM within visual range, to allow a stealthy-configured F-35C to move between the two regimes. It’s a known tactic that has been used in combat, notably by TOPGUN graduate Navy Lieutenant Commander  Michael “Mob” Tremel over Syria in June 2017. Part of TOPGUN’s charter is to address these kinds of issues, to find fixes and to promote best practices. These unique issues with the F-35C are exactly what TOPGUN experts will have scrutinized and fed back into the system in order to evolve the syllabus.
  NAWDC executed a dry run of the syllabus in late 2019 using just TOPGUN instructors, before the first live course with students started earlier this year. Moreover, Air Test and Evaluation Squadron Nine (VX-9), the “Vampires,” played a major part in building the F-35C into the TOPGUN course, especially given its wide spectrum of operations.
 The F-35C adds a deep strike into highly contested environments capability to the carrier air wing, but in addition, the aircraft will fly Destruction of Enemy Air Defense (DEAD) alongside its Offensive Counter-Air (OCA) and Defensive Counter-Air (DCA) mission sets.
 Other changes the F-35C is likely to bring to the existing TOPGUN course include the use of stealth tactics in the BVR arena with the pilot acting as a battle manager, monitoring the 80 x 20-inch touch screen cockpit display, showing data sucked up via a dizzying array of advanced sensors. The F-35 pilot has a distinct advantage due to the aircraft’s extreme degree of sensor fusion. The jet’s AN/APG-81  active electronically scanned array (AESA) radar, Electro-Optical Targeting System  (EOTS), Distributed Aperture System (DAS), and its highly advanced  electronic surveillance and electronic warfare suite work together to provide its pilot with unprecedented situational awareness. Altogether, the F-35C represents a significant leap in technology compared to the Navy’s Super Hornets that are currently in service.
 Being a 13-week course, TOPGUN cannot offer the same levels of detail as say the six-month-long USAF Weapons Instructor Course (WIC) at Nellis. The complexity of the F-35C means that the syllabus that is taught at Fallon may need to expand or otherwise have added elements bolted on. TOPGUN’s focus on air-to-air combat may not ideally lend itself to the kind of advanced mission package leadership that deep strike missions could require. However, TOPGUN’s work with the F-35C will be influential in building the corporate knowledge that is required within the U.S. Navy that leads to successfully employing the full capabilities of the jet.
   “Graduating Strike Fighter Tactics Instructors allows us to accelerate learning by feeding TOPGUN training back to the fleet, elevating the lethality and survivability of both the individual aircraft as well as the Carrier Strike Group. The Lightning II proved its value to the Navy during every phase of the TOPGUN course, and its integration with the F/A-18E/F Super Hornet, EA-18G Growler and E-2C/D Hawkeye demonstrated that the powerful combination of 4th and 5th generation fighters, with advanced electronic attack, and command and control, is a force-multiplier against advanced threats.”
 Since completing the TOPGUN course in May, Heinz and Goodwin have returned to instruct and train their squadronmates, with a particular emphasis on ensuring that pilots will have the requisite skill sets to effectively employ the F-35C during its first operational deployment.
 “Our focus is on assisting the SFTIs at the operational fleet squadron pushing the big picture tactics and ensuring that everything is ready to go for the first and subsequent F-35C carrier deployments. The idea is that VFA-147 SFTIs can use the standards of tactical execution we provide to train their own people and take that knowledge with them through deployment. We are here to ensure that they are set up for success."
 "While my role as an F-35C instructor is still primarily focused on the students at the FRS, my perspective on what I teach and how I teach it most certainly has grown since completing TOPGUN,” added Maj Heinz. “I’m still training students to fly the aircraft, it’s just now I have the additional responsibility as an SFTI to bring that advanced training to the fleet, while helping maintain the TOPGUN training syllabus and ensuring standardization of training for all instructors. We are always working to maintain the highest standards of training.”
  Since the stand up of Commander, Joint Strike Fighter Wing in August 2018 at Lemoore, the program has declared Safe-for-Flight Operations Certification (SFFOC) for both VFA-147 and the USMC’s first F-35C unit, Marine Fighter Attack Squadron 314 (VMFA-314), the "Black Knights." VFA-147 is now preparing for the first-ever F-35C carrier deployment, as part of Carrier Air Wing Two (CVW-2) aboard the  Nimitz class aircraft carrier USS  Carl Vinson (CVN-70) next year. Navy Captain Adan Covarrubias, Commander of Joint Strike Fighter Wing, said in a release:
 "The tactics that were developed during this first F-35C class are currently being integrated into the carrier air wing’s work-up cycle, truly making them a more lethal carrier and air wing of the future."
 Completion of the first F-35C course at TOPGUN was very well-timed. VFA-147 recently arrived en masse at NAS Fallon to begin the squadron’s work-ups for the forthcoming carrier deployment, complete with its new TOPGUN-graduate Strike Fighter Tactics Instructor, who is already setting the pace for the squadron. Considering the unit could find itself called into combat in any of many hotspots around the globe during the type's very first cruise, having a recent graduate from TOPGUN in its ranks gives the Argonauts a huge advantage.
 It will greatly help ensure that whatever missions the squadron may be tasked with are successful and that every F-35C pilot comes home alive.
 Author’s Note: The WarZone reached out to TOPGUN to discuss the specifics of the new F-35 course, but operational security prevented any further comment.

旧金山厨师克里斯蒂安·西斯克(Christian Ciscle)本周在社交媒体上引起了人们对这笔费用的关注。西斯科在旧金山教会区经营着一家颇受欢迎的炸鸡店。他在推特上发布了DoorDash的一条消息的截图，显示佣金率为30%。
DoorDash后来就这条推文联系了Ciscle，告诉他这条推文并没有反映出他实际上被收取的较低佣金费率。但DoorDash的一名代表告诉“纪事报”，旧金山还有其他餐厅，在该公司与之合作的数千家餐厅中，只有不到10家实际上错误地收取了30%的佣金。该公司表示，将补偿错误收取的费用。
DoorDash在给“纪事报”的一封电子邮件中说：“我们对这种情况造成的任何混乱表示遗憾，并正在积极努力，让我们的商业合作伙伴更清楚地了解我们目前的佣金结构。”
对于Ciscle来说，当涉及到与送货应用程序相关的费用时，他在公司的经历代表着旧金山餐厅的一个更大的问题。

今年早些时候，监管人员亚伦·佩斯金(Aaron Peskin)和艾莎·萨法伊(Ahsha Safaí)发起谈判，限制优步(Uber Eats)、GrubHub、DoorDash和Postmate等送餐公司的佣金，作为对就地避难所订单对餐厅财务影响的紧急回应。当伦敦布赖德市长在4月份宣布这项立法时，旧金山成为加州第一个代表餐馆采取此类行动的城市。这项立法要求被发现违反上限的第三方应用程序向通知他们多收费用的餐厅提供退款。
今年6月，GrubHub曾短暂开始向一些当地餐厅收取超过15%的费用。格鲁布中心在一份声明中告诉SFGate，在旧金山最初的上限到期后，费用上调了。
作为回应，市政府官员修改了上限的措辞，以澄清，当修改避难所就地令以允许在旧金山室内就餐时，上限将终止。
这可能需要一段时间。作为当地重新开业计划的一部分，旧金山的餐厅在6月份获准提供户外用餐服务。从7月13日开始，室内用餐将被允许。该计划于周二被取消，因为数据显示病毒感染正在加州各地爆炸式增长。

“我们还没有走出困境，”布赖德在周二的新闻发布会上说。
在大流行期间，送货应用市场对旧金山餐厅的重要性与日俱增。根据最近的数据，即使在下单之前，美国就有大约4000万第三方送货应用程序用户。在过去的几个月里，这个数字有所增长。但是，尽管这些服务在顾客中很受欢迎，旧金山的厨师们长期以来一直在抱怨与DoorDash做生意的成本。
这种情况刺激了当地餐馆之间的演变。一些人放弃了这些应用程序，转而创建自己的内部送货服务业务，就像旧金山任务区的Prairie所做的那样。
草原主人安东尼·斯特朗最近告诉“纪事报”：“对我们所有人来说，拥有自己的东西是一个更好的选择。”

Numerous San Francisco restaurants trying to survive on takeout service during the pandemic have also quietly been dealing with an unexpected financial hurdle: 30% commission fees from DoorDash, despite the fact that  the city capped fees charged by food delivery apps at 15% in April.
  San Francisco chef Christian Ciscle, who runs a popular fried chicken spot in San Francisco’s Mission District, drew attention to the fees  on social media this week. He posted a screenshot on Twitter of a message from DoorDash that showed a 30% commission rate.
  DoorDash later contacted Ciscle about the tweet, and told him it did not reflect the lower commission rate he was actually being charged. But a DoorDash representative told The Chronicle there were other restaurants in San Francisco, fewer than 10 out of the thousands the company works with in the city, that were actually mistakenly being charged 30% commission rates. The company said it will reimburse the incorrectly charged fees.
  “We regret any confusion caused in this instance and are actively working to make the communication around our current commission structure clearer for our merchant partners,” DoorDash said in an email to The Chronicle.
  For Ciscle, his experience with the company represents a larger issue for San Francisco restaurants when it comes to the fees tied to delivery apps.
  “It was impossible for restaurants before COVID to survive with all of these apps and their fees,” Ciscle, owner of SF Chickenbox, told The Chronicle. “If you’re giving 25% to 30% to an app, there’s no way you’re going to survive, or even get ahead.”
     Supervisors Aaron Peskin and Ahsha Safaí initiated talks to cap commission fees from food delivery companies like Uber Eats, Grubhub, DoorDash and Postmates earlier this year as an emergency response to the financial impact of shelter-in-place orders on restaurants. When Mayor London Breed announced the legislation in April, San Francisco became the first city in California to take such action  on behalf of restaurants. The legislation requires third-party apps found to be in violation of the cap to provide refunds to restaurants who notify them they were overcharged.
  In June, Grubhub briefly  began charging some local restaurants more than 15% in fees. The hike in fees followed the expiration of San Francisco’s initial cap, Grubhub told SFGate in a statement.
  In response,  city officials amended the language of the cap to clarify that it will terminate when the shelter-in-place order is amended to allow indoor dining in San Francisco.
  That may take a while. San Francisco restaurants were allowed to offer outdoor meal service in June as part of the local reopening plan. Indoor dining was due to be allowed beginning July 13. That  plan was nixed Tuesday as data showed viral infections were exploding across California.
  In the Bay Area, the number of people hospitalized with COVID-19 climbed to 504 patients as of Tuesday, according to state data. Contra Costa, Marin, Napa, San Mateo, Santa Clara and Sonoma counties all reported single-day hospitalization increases.
     “We are not out of the woods yet,” Breed said during a news conference on Tuesday.
  The delivery-app market has grown in importance to San Francisco restaurants during pandemic. Even before shelter-in-place orders, there were around 40 million third-party delivery app users in the U.S., according to recent data. The numbers have grown over the past few months. But while the services are popular among customers, San Francisco  chefs have long bemoaned the cost of doing business with the DoorDashes of the world.
  The situation has spurred an evolution among local restaurants. Some have dropped the apps in favor of creating their own in-house delivery service operations, as Prairie in San Francisco’s Mission District has done.
  “Having our own thing was just a better option for us all around,” Prairie owner Anthony Strong recently told The Chronicle.
  Update: This story has been updated to clarify aspects of Christian Ciscle’s interaction with DoorDash. He received a message from DoorDash noting a 30% commission rate on deliveries.

由加州大学洛杉矶分校(UCLA)材料科学家领导的一个研究小组已经展示了制造超白涂料的方法，这种涂料可以反射高达98%的太阳传入热量。这一进展展示了设计油漆的实用途径，如果在屋顶和建筑的其他部分使用这些油漆，可以显著降低冷却成本，这超出了标准的白色凉爽屋顶油漆所能达到的效果。发表在“焦耳”(Joule)杂志网站上的这一发现，是通过白天被动辐射来保持建筑物降温的重要而实用的一步。被动辐射是一种自发过程，表面反射阳光，将热量辐射到空间，冷却到潜在的亚环境温度。这可以降低室内温度，并有助于减少空调的使用和相关的二氧化碳排放。
加州大学洛杉矶分校萨缪利工程学院(UCLA Samueli School Of Engineering)材料科学与工程学助理教授、这项研究的首席研究员阿斯瓦思·拉曼(Aaswath Raman)说，在炎热的阳光灿烂的日子里，当你穿着白色T恤时，你会感觉比穿深色T恤更凉爽--这是因为白色衬衫能反射更多阳光，同样的概念也适用于建筑。阿斯瓦思·拉曼是加州大学洛杉矶分校萨缪利工程学院(UCLA Samueli School Of Engineering)材料科学与工程学助理教授，也是这项研究的主要研究员。粉刷成白色的屋顶内部会比深色的屋顶凉爽。但这些颜料还能做别的事情：它们能阻挡红外线波长的热量，而这是我们人类用肉眼看不见的。这可以让建筑物通过辐射冷却进一步降温。
目前市场上性能最好的白色涂料通常能反射大约85%的入射太阳辐射。其余的被化学成分吸收。研究人员表明，对油漆成分进行简单的修改就可以提供显著的跳跃，反射高达98%的入射辐射。
目前的白色涂料具有很高的太阳反射率，使用的是氧化钛。虽然该化合物对大多数可见光和近红外光的反射率很高，但它也能吸收紫外线和紫外光。这种化合物的紫外线吸收特性使其在防晒霜中很有用，但它们也会导致阳光下的加热-这阻碍了尽可能保持凉爽。
研究人员研究了用廉价和容易获得的成分取代氧化钛，如重晶石，这是一种艺术家的颜料，以及动力聚四氟乙烯，更为人所知的是特氟龙。这些成分可以帮助油漆反射紫外线。该团队还对涂料的配方进行了进一步的改进，包括降低聚合物粘合剂的浓度，聚合物粘合剂也会吸收热量。
加州大学洛杉矶分校(UCLA)博士后学者乔奥蒂莫伊·曼达尔(Jyotirmoy Mandal)说，这样做可能会在不久的将来实现潜在的降温效益，因为我们提出的修改方案在油漆和涂料行业的能力范围内。他是施密特科学公司(Schmidt Science)的研究员，也是这项研究的共同通讯作者。
除了这一进展，作者们还提出了进一步研究的几个长期影响，包括绘制这种颜料可以发挥作用的地方的地图，研究污染对技术的影响，以及在全球范围内，如果它们能够削弱地球自身反射太阳热量的能力的话。
研究人员还指出，包括加利福尼亚州和纽约市在内的许多市政当局和政府已经开始鼓励新建筑的凉爽屋顶技术。
研究冷却涂料技术多年的曼达尔说，我们希望这项工作将刺激未来在超白涂料方面的倡议，不仅可以节省建筑能源，还可以减轻城市的热岛效应，甚至可能展示一种实用的方式，如果大规模应用，可能会影响气候变化。曼达尔研究冷却涂料技术已有数年。这将需要光学、材料科学和气象学等不同领域的专家以及来自行业和政策部门的专家之间的合作。更多信息：Jyotirmoy Mandal等人，Joule(2020)，Paints as a Scalable and Efficient Radiative Cooling Technology for Building，Joule(2020)。doi：10.1016/j.joule.2020.04.010
note_en:
A research team led by UCLA materials scientists has demonstrated ways to make super white paint that reflects as much as 98% of incoming heat from the sun. The advance shows practical pathways for designing paints that, if used on rooftops and other parts of a building, could significantly reduce cooling costs, beyond what standard white 'cool-roof' paints can achieve.    The findings, published online in  Joule, are a major and practical step towards keeping buildings cooler by passive daytime radiative  —a spontaneous process in which a surface reflects sunlight and radiates heat into space, cooling down to potentially sub-ambient temperatures. This can lower indoor temperatures and help cut down on air conditioner use and associated carbon dioxide emissions.
  "When you wear a white T-shirt on a hot sunny day, you feel cooler than if you wore one that's darker in color—that's because the white shirt reflects more sunlight and it's the same concept for buildings," said Aaswath Raman, an assistant professor of materials science and engineering at UCLA Samueli School of Engineering, and the principal investigator on the study. "A roof painted white will be cooler inside than one in a darker shade. But those paints also do something else: they reject heat at infrared wavelengths, which we humans cannot see with our eyes. This could allow buildings to cool down even more by radiative cooling."
  The best performing white paints currently available typically reflect around 85% of incoming solar radiation. The remainder is absorbed by the chemical makeup of the  . The researchers showed that simple modifications in a paint's ingredients could offer a significant jump, reflecting as much as 98% of incoming radiation.
  Current white paints with high solar reflectance use titanium oxide. While the compound is very reflective of most visible and near-infrared light, it also absorbs ultraviolet and violet light. The compound's UV absorption qualities make it useful in sunscreen lotions, but they also lead to heating under sunlight—which gets in the way of keeping a   as cool as possible.
  The researchers examined replacing titanium oxide with inexpensive and readily available ingredients such as barite, which is an artist's pigment, and powered polytetrafluoroethylene, better known as Teflon. These ingredients help paints reflect UV light. The team also made further refinements to the paint's formula, including reducing the concentration of polymer binders, which also absorb heat.
  "The potential cooling benefits this can yield may be realized in the near future because the modifications we propose are within the capabilities of the paint and coatings industry," said UCLA postdoctoral scholar Jyotirmoy Mandal, a Schmidt Science Fellow working in Raman's research group and the co-corresponding author on the research.
  Beyond the advance, the authors suggested several long-term implications for further study, including mapping where such paints could make a difference, studying the effect of pollution on   technologies, and on a global scale, if they could make a dent on the earth's own ability to reflect heat from the sun.
  The researchers also noted that many municipalities and governments, including the state of California and New York City, have started to encourage cool-roof technologies for new buildings.
  "We hope that the work will spur future initiatives in super-white coatings for not only energy savings in buildings, but also mitigating the heat island effects of cities, and perhaps even showing a practical way that, if applied on a massive, global scale could affect climate change," said Mandal, who has studied cooling paint technologies for several years. "This would require a collaboration among experts in diverse fields like optics, materials science and meteorology, and experts from the industry and policy sectors."        More information:												Jyotirmoy Mandal et al, Paints as a Scalable and Effective Radiative Cooling Technology for Buildings,  Joule (2020).  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2020.04.010

title_en: Keeping buildings cooler with super-white paints
